questions.clue: In 1900, this sport was played with a live animal, making it unique in Olympic history.
In 1904, the marathon event at the St. Louis Olympics featured this unusual activity by runner Fred Lorz.
Eddie 'The Eagle' became famous during the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics by competing in this discipline despite finishing last.
In the 1936 Berlin Olympics, this nation's bamboo pole vaulting team stood out due to non-standard equipment.
This city hosted the 1900 Olympics, which oddly included a 60-meter prostate hurdle race and no podiums for medal ceremonies.
For 200 points: Known as the 'Sport of Kings', polo is played by Prince Andrey in this Russian author's work 'War and Peace'.
For 400 points: Cricket is a recurring motif in the novel 'A Suitable Boy' by this Indian author.
For 600 points: This Hemingway novel, featuring bullfighting, established Ernest Hemingway as a key writer of the Lost Generation.
For 800 points: Golf serves as a backdrop in this F. Scott Fitzgerald novel, where character Jordan Baker is a professional golfer.
For 1000 points: This Jack London novel includes scenes of competitive sled dog racing and follows Buck, a St. Bernard-Scotch Collie.
This stadium, nicknamed 'La Bombonera,' is known for its steep stands and is home to Boca Juniors in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Opened in 1972, this Munich stadium was the site of both the Olympics and the first major legal futsal match in its inaugural year.
Designed by Japanese architect Arata Isozaki, this Palau was completed in 1990 and serves as the main basketball venue in Barcelona.
Located in New Jersey, it's the only stadium that serves as the home to two NFL teams, the Jets and the Giants, and is one of the largest in the NFL.
This arena, notable for its retractable pitch and roof, is the largest domed structure in the world and was built for the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney.
Just like a perfectly executed penalty goal in soccer, this law states every action has an equal and opposite reaction.
This effect, named after an Austrian physicist, describes how the sound of a passing race car changes as it moves toward and then away from you.
In a stadium 'wave,' you see a pattern emerge; similarly, this phenomenon can occur when waves combine to form a larger wave.
Just like a basketball player conserving energy throughout a game, this principle states that energy in a closed system remains constant.
In this theoretical state, temperature is so low that atoms stop moving, akin to a freeze in a mid-game time-out.
In 1920, this national organization was formed to oversee Major League Baseball.
This American swimmer won 8 gold medals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
In 1991, this basketball player changed sports by signing a minor league baseball contract with the Chicago White Sox.
In 1960, this boxer, then known as Cassius Clay, won the light heavyweight gold medal at the Rome Olympics.
In 1953, this tennis legend became the first man to win the Grand Slam, achieving victories in all four major championships in a single calendar year.

final.clue: In 1999, this athlete became the first to win four major women's tennis singles titles in a calendar year since Steffi Graf in 1993.
